case: A 73-year-old Black presents with acute, severe, pleuritic, central, non-radiating chest pain, and tachycardia after undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy.
A 73-year-old Black presents with acute, severe, pleuritic, central, non-radiating chest pain, and tachycardia after undergoing an esophagogastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy.
differential: Pneumothorax (especially post-procedure, possibly due to barotrauma from endoscopy)
Perforation of esophagus or gastrointestinal tract (post-procedure complication)
Acute coronary syndrome (though pain is pleuritic, cannot rule out atypical presentation)
Pulmonary embolism (given pleuritic chest pain and tachycardia)
Pericarditis (pleuritic pain, but less likely post-procedure)
Aortic dissection (less likely without radiation or other features, but possible)
Esophageal spasm or reflux (less likely given severity and pleuritic nature)
Musculoskeletal pain (e.g., costochondritis, though less likely given acuity and severity)
Pleural effusion (less likely without other features)
